MissionCommands.Message: Welcome to the ECS lesson! This is an important lesson, and the ECS is a complex system that is important to understand. I hope you have read the ECS chapter in the Flight Manual before starting this?
The environmental control system is designed to provide the flight crew with a conditioned environment that is both life-supporting, and as comfortable as possible.

You will spend long days and nights up in the Command Module. To do that, it is important that something make it possible to stay alive there, be comfortable, and can provide you with blankets when you will sleep.
To make this possible, multiple systems in the environmental control system will work together. Both primary and redundant systems are available, as the ECS is critical during the entire mission.
It will help you with three main things. 1) atmosphere control, 2) water, 3) thermal. That's basically what you need to stay alive, in addition to some provisions we ship with the spacecraft.
It sounds quite simple, but when you think about it, the system will need to manage the pressure and the temperature of the cabin with breathable oxygen.
As you breathe, you generate water and CO2, both needs to be removed to not get a humid cockpit or give you CO2 poisoning. Odors and particulate matter must also be removed.

During the mission, it is also important to drink water. Water is also needed by the ECS to operate. Luckily there are two sources of water in the spacecraft. The water the ECS removes from the air you breathe out, and the water that gets produced by the Fuel Cells when O2 and H2 generates power.

The ECS can gather water from the air and feed it to the water requirements of the ECS. It needs water for part of the cooling mechanisms. We call this water “Waste Water” and it is stored in dedicated tank.

The water from the fuel cells is clean enough to be consumed by you and can be used to make hot coffee in space. In addition, the ECS can use this water too if needed. We call this potable water, and it is stored in another dedicated water tank.

You, as well as most of the electrical components, generate a lot of heat and requires cooling to not fail. A coolant is used to do this. It goes around most of the electrical components, picks up their heat, and transfers it to the radiators that will radiate it to space, or use part of it for temperature control in the cockpit.
So, let’s dive onto the details. We will start with the Oxygen subsystem.

The spacecraft comes with two primary oxygen tanks stored in the SM. They are used by the fuel cells, as well as the ECS. The O2 from these tanks goes into the Command Module where it is heated (so you don’t need to breathe cryogenic gas) before reaching the S/M SUPPLY valve.
This valve is controlled by you and is located on the panel right below the commander’s window, P326. This is usually open/ON until SM separation. Verify that this is ON.
So where will you get oxygen from when the SM is separated, as it takes both the primary oxygen tanks with it?

The O2 Surge Tank and the Portable Life Support System (PLSS) tanks gives you this. Both tanks can be used and refilled during the mission when the S/M SUPPLY line is pressurized, and once separated, they take over.

Nominally, the oxygen is stored with a pressure of about 900 psig in all of these tanks and lines. This can be seen on MDC-2. The O2 PRESS IND sw can be used to see the pressure in the main tank 1, or in the surge tank.

Once the O2 enters the Command Module it branches off into two directions. One along it’s “main line”, and another that goes into the SURGE TANK through a valve. This valve is operated on P326 as well. Set this to OFF for now.

If this is ON, and the Surge Tank has less pressure than the main line, the Surge Tank will be refilled. The Surge Tank will then augment the S/M SUPPLY line if needed. In the OFF position it will be isolated.

Continuing along the main line, the gas will meet another junction. Along the main line, the gas will go to the MAIN REGULATORS, or branch off to the Portable Life Support System. The REPRESS PKG VALVE is the entry point for the PLSS.

Inside the PLSS branch you will find three oxygen tanks, each storing 1 LB of O2, so a total of 3 LB. These three tanks can also be refilled, or augment the main line. In addition, the PLSS system can inject this oxygen into the cabin if it needs to be repressurized, or provide oxygen to the emergency oxygen masks.

The PLSS is mainly operated from panel 600, 601 and 602, above the LMPs head. The pressure in the system can be read on panel 602. On panel 601, a valve can be used to dump the oxygen into the cabin at a very high rate. It can fill the cabin from 0 to 3 psi in one minute.

Set the REPRESS PKG valve to the FILL position. When full, the surge tank pressure on the CRYOGENIC TANK PRESSURE O2 1 indicator will read 900+/-35 psi. At this point, both the surge tank and the package tanks are full.

The MAIN REGULATOR reduces the supply pressure to 85-110 psig for use by the subsystem components. You have two main regulators, A and B. The output of the main regulators passes through a flowmeter, and can be seen on the O2 FLOW indicator on the top of MDC-2.
Nominal flow for metabolic consumption and cabin leakage is approximately 0.45 pound per hour.

Flow rates of 1 pound per hour or more with a duration of 16 seconds will illuminate the O2 FLOW HI light on the caution and warning panel. The warning is intended to alert the crew to the fact that the oxygen flow rate is greater than is normally required. This can be OK it some cases.

After the main regulator, the main gas line will again branch off into multiple subsystems. One of them is the WATER & GLYCOL TANK PRESSURE branch. The gas will pressurize the Potable Water, Waste Water and the Glycol reservoir so they can be used by the ECS system.
The valves into this branch are operated on panel 351. Verify the regulators are set to BOTH.
The relief valves are used to relief excess pressure in the system. Verify it's set to BOTH.

Another system the gas will reach is the cabin pressure regulator. This system controls the flow of oxygen into the cabin to make up for depletion of gas due to metabolic consumption, normal leakage, or for repressurization.
The regulator is designed to maintain a cabin pressure at 5 psia at flow rates up to 1.4 pounds per hour.
When the cabin pressure falls to 3.5 psia minimum, the regulator will automatically shut off to prevent wasting the oxygen supply.
Following depressurization, the cabin can be repressurized by manually opening the CABIN REPRESS valve. Verify that this is CLOSED.
The next system is the EMERGENCY CABIN PRESSURE. The regulator provides emergency protection for the crew in the event of severe leak in the cabin.
The regulator valve starts to open when cabin pressure decreases to 4.6 psia; and at 4.2 psia the valve is full-open, flooding the cabin with oxygen.
During pressure suit operations, the regulator is shut off to prevent unnecessary loss of oxygen in case of unplanned cabin depressurization. Set this to OFF now.

Let’s continue to the next system the gas will reach after the MAIN REGULATORS. The CABIN RELIEF VALVE is used to relief the cabin of excess pressure, and will maintain cabin pressure at 5 psia. Excess pressure will be relieved overboard.
The CABIN PRESSURE RELIEF valves are controlled on panel 325. During ascent and entry, this is set to BOOST/ENTRY. During normal operation, the valves are set to NORMAL.

Lastly, the O2 DEMAND REGULATOR, controlled on P380, supplies oxygen to the suit circuit. It will try to maintain a pressure close to the cabin pressure, or at 3.5 if in depressurized conditions. The DIRECT O2 valve on panel 7 can also directly supply oxygen to the circuit. Verify that the DIRECT O2 valve is fully closed.
Now, that was a lot of information. Let’s try to use to perform a few important operations in the cabin. We will first depressurize the cabin, then repressurize it again.
First, with the Emergency O2 system OFF so it does not try to pressurize the cabin, we can try to depressurize the cabin.
The procedures for doing this is in the SYSTEMS: ECS section in the checklists tab for the Command Module. Take a look at them for reference.
Start by setting the Cabin Fan 1 to OFF (down).
Then set Cabin Fan 2 to OFF as well. The fans should not operate in a depressurized cabin.
The DIRECT O2 selector on P7 should be fully closed, but verify this again.
The next thing we will do is to start dumping the cabin air to space. Set the pressure relief valve 1 to dump.
Open the 2nd valve as well.
Then check the cabin pressure indicator on MDC-2. It should show that the cabin is decreasing.

It is important that you have a good overview of what systems that can repressurize and depressurize the cabin, so you know you wont waste O2 by venting the cabin while a system then tries to pressurize it at the same time. Use the O2 Flow indicator to verify.
When the cabin reached 0.0, the cabin is depressurized.
Another option to depressurize the cabin instead of using the pressure relief valves is to use the cabin pressure dump valve on the side-hatch. Verify that this is closed.
Set the cabin pressure relief valve 1 back to NORMAL.
Then set the cabin pressure relief valve 2 back to NORMAL as well.
The next procedure we will look at is the cabin repressurize procedures. Open the checklist for it for reference.
We will deviate from the checklist a bit to show some concepts. We will try to only use the PLSS tanks to pressurize the cabin to about 3 psia.
To do this, we will set the PLSS valve to OFF, to isolate if from the supply gas circuit.
We will then open the REPRESS O2 VALVE on panel 601 (above your head) to let the PLSS dump all of its oxygen into the cabin.
As O2 enters, you can monitor the PLSS tank PSI on the gauge on panel 602, and the cabin pressure indicator on MDC-2.
When the cabin reaches about 3.0 psia or that the PLSS is empty (0 psi on the 602 gauge), close the REPRESS O2 VALVE again.
We will then set the REPRESS PKG to FILL so that the PLSS tank can be refilled.

Then we will use the CABIN REPRESS valve on panel 351 to repressurize the cabin. The S/M SUPPLY and/or the SURGE TANK valves (P326) must be open so that the gas can reach the cabin repressurization system.
Open it to the maximum setting and monitor the CABIN PRESSURE indicator on MDC-2.
When the cabin pressure reached 5.0, close the valve again.
Since the cabin pressure is above 3.5, the cabin pressure regulators and the demand regulators will ty to maintain cabin pressure to about 5.0.
From the oxygen supply system, the gas will enter the pressure suit circuit (PSC).

The pressure suit circuit (PSC) is a circulating gas loop which provides you with continuously conditioned atmosphere throughout the mission. The gas is circulated through the PSC by two centrifugal compressors, which are controlled by individual switches on panel 4.

The compressors require AC power, and each can be connected to either AC. Throughout the mission, when performing the ECS REDUNDANT COMPONENT checklist, you will switch what compressor that will be active, so both will be used over the mission in cycles.
Set the suit compressor 1 to AC1 and leave the suit compressor 2 in OFF.

When the suit compressor is active, the SUIT COMPR ΔP PRESSURE indicator on MDC-2 should show about 0.45 PSI. If this drops below 0.22 PSI (compressor has failed or turned off), the master alarm will trigger, and the SUIT COMPRESSOR warning light will illuminate. We will test this soon!

The gas leaving the compressor flows through the CO2 and odor absorber assembly. The assembly is a dual unit containing two absorber elements in separate compartments with inlet and outlet manifolds common to both.

A diverter valve in the inlet manifold provides a means of isolating one compartment or the other for the purpose of replacing a spent absorber. One absorber lasts for about 12 hours to stay below the 7.6 mm Hg CO2 level.
The CO2 level can be seen on the PART PRESS CO2 indicator on MDC-2. If this exceeds 7.6 mm Hg, a warning will be triggered, and CO2 PP HI will illuminate.

From the filter the gas flows through the suit heat exchanger where the gases are cooled and the excess moisture is removed. The suit heat exchanger uses coolant to cool the gas. The coolant flow/bypass is controlled on the coolant control panel (382). Set it to flow.
When it is set to FLOW, it can be controlled on the MDC-2 using the SUIT CIRCUIT HEAT EXCH sw. Set it to ON.
As the gases are cooled to about 55 °F, the excess moisture condenses out and is removed from the heat exchanger by one or both of a pair of water accumulator pumps.

The water accumulators are piston-type pumps, which are actuated by oxygen pressure. The oxygen flow is controlled by the two WATER ACCUMULATOR selector valve assemblies located on the COOLANT CONTROL PANEL (382).
I did not mention this earlier, but the oxygen that goes to the WATER ACCUMULATORs comes for the oxygen supply system.

When the selector valve is in the RMTE position, oxygen flow is controlled by the solenoid valve. The solenoid valve can be controlled automatically by signals from the central timing equipment by placing the SUIT CIRCUIT-H2O ACCUM switch (panel 2) in either AUTO 1 or AUTO 2.

In the automatic mode the central timing equipment signal will cause one of the accumulators to complete a cycle every ten minutes. The water is pumped to the waste water tank for use by the evaporators.

The cool gas (55 °F nominal) flows from the heat exchanger through the suit flow limiters and the flow control valves, into the suits. The suit temperature is measured at the heat exchanger outlet, and is displayed on the SUIT TEMP indicator (panel 2).

The flow control valves (panels 300, 301, 302) are part of the suit hose connector assembly. These valves provide a means for adjusting the gas flow through each suit individually, and are fully modulating from OFF to the FULL FLOW position.

The gas leaving the suits flows through the debris trap assembly, into the suit compressor. The debris trap is a mechanical filter for screening out solid matter that might otherwise clog or damage the suit compressors.

The SUIT CIRCUIT RETURN VALVE (panel 380) is installed on the debris trap upstream of the screen. The valve permits the cabin gases to enter the suit circuit for scrubbing. The manual VALVE provides a means for isolating the suit circuit from the cabin.
This is done to prevent inducting cabin gases into the suit circuit, in the event the cabin gases become contaminated.

Let’s try some of this out. First, set the suit compressors to OFF. This will stop the gas from circulating in the PSC. This is not good, and a master alarm will be triggered. Press the MASTER ALARM pb to silence the alarm.
As the PSC isn’t circulated, the air will become contaminated and the CO2 level will rise. Use timescale for about 5 minutes, and monitor the increase of CO2.
Use timescale to increase it a bit more until the the CO2 PP HI light is illuminated. Silence the MASTER ALARM again, and enable the suit compressor.
As the filter is working, the CO2 canisters will start to fill up. The fuller they get, the less CO2 they will absorb. They should be replaced every 12 hours.
To replace it, open the CO2 CANISTER panel (P350), move the handle to the side (they are directed towards the center), press C, and click REPLACE. Do this now.
After replacing it, set the handle back towards the center.
Now, let's dive into the water subsystem!
The water subsystem consists of two individual fluid management networks which control the collection storage, and distribution of potable and waste water.
The potable water is used primarily for metabolic purposes. The waste water is used solely as the evaporator in the primary and secondary glycol evaporators.
Potable water produced in the fuel cells is pumped into the CM at a flow rate of approximately 1.5 pounds per hour.
The water flow through a hydrogen separator to the inlet ports of the POTABLE TANK INLET and WASTE TANK INLET valves (panel 352). Both should be OPEN/AUTO.
The POTABLE TANK INLET is a manual shutoff valve used for preventing the flow of fuel cell water into the potable system in the event the fuel cell water becomes contaminated.
The pH HI talkback (panel 3) shows a “barberpole” when the water pH factor exceeds a value of 9.
The WASTE TANK INLET will let water enter the waste water system if there is a need. It can be because the POTABLE WATER tank is full or closed, or empty while the evaporators require water.
In the event that both water tanks are full at the time the fuel cells are pumping, the excess potable water will be dumped overboard through the PRESSURE RELIEF valve on panel 352.
Setting it to DUMP A or DUMP B will vent a constant stream of water from the waste tank into space.
During flight the waste water tank will be maintained below 75 percent by manually dumping the excess water.
Quantity transducers provides signals to the H2O QUANTITY indicator on panel 2. The signal source is selected by the H2O QTY IND switch located below and to the left of the indicator on panel 2.
Pressure to the water subsystem is received from the oxygen supply subsystem.
Waste water extracted from the suit heat exchanger is pumped into the waste water tank, and is delivered to the EVAP WATER CONTROL-PRIMARY and SECONDARY valves on panel 382.
When the tank is full, excess waste water is dumped overboard through the water PRESSURE RELIEF valve.
The EVAP WATER CONTROL valves consist of a manually operated inlet valve and a solenoid valve. When the inlet valves are in AUTO, the solenoid valves control water flow to the evaporators.

The PRIMARY solenoid valve is controlled automatically when the GLYCOL-EVAP-H2O FLOW switch (panel 2) is in AUTO, and manually when the switch is ON. The SECONDARY solenoid valve is controlled automatically when the SEC COOLANT LOOP EVAP switch is in EVAP.
Next we will dive into the glycol and radiator subsystems. It consists of two independently operated closed coolant loops, the primary and the secondary coolant loop.
The primary loop is operated continuously throughout the mission unless damage to the equipment necessitates shutdown.
The secondary loop provides a backup for the primary loop. Due to the length of this lesson, it will not be covered in detail.

Both loops provide cooling for the suit and cabin atmosphere, the electric equipment, and a portion of the potable water supply. The primary loop also serves as a source of heat for the cabin atmosphere when required.
The primary loop has two pumps and an accumulator that circulates the coolant, while the secondary has one pump and an accumulator for the job.
The accumulators are used to create a positive pressure at the inlets of the pumps, and their quantity can be read on the ACCUM PRIM/SEC indicator on MDC-2.
Only one of the two pumps in the primary loop can be active at a time, and is controlled by the ECS GLYCOL PUMPS on panel 4. They can be connected to either a-c bus. Use Pump 1 in AC1.
The glycol is usually hot at this point in the loop. It is first used to de-ice the valve throat of the evaporator steam pressure control.

The hot glycol then normally needs to be cooled down. It reached a GLYCOL TO RADIATORS valve controlled by the GLYCOL TO RADIATORS-PRIM handle on panel 325. If open, the glycol goes through the radiators, cools down, and the returns to the CM.
This is on bypass during the ascent as the radiators will be hot, and after SM-separation to prevent the coolant to vent to space. During space operations the valve is in the NORMAL position.

Coolant returning to the CM flows to the GLYCOL RESERVOIR valves (panel 326). From prelaunch until orbit insertion, the reservoir INLET and OUTLET valves are open and the bypass valve is closed, allowing coolant to circulate through the reservoir.

After orbit insertion, the reservoir is isolated from the primary loop by opening the BYPASS valve, and closing the INLET and OUTLET valves to provide a reserve supply of coolant for refilling the loop in the event of a leak occurs. Close the INLET.
Then close the OUTLET.
From the outlet or bypass valve, the coolant will go to the glycol evaporator. This will be explained later.

Then some of the cold coolant goes through the IMU and the coldplate network, while most of it goes through a water chiller, to cool the water you will be drinking, the suit heat exchanger valve operated on panel 382 and the cabin temperature control on panel 303.

The PRIMARY CABIN TEMP control valve routes the coolant to either the cabin heat exchanger or the coldplate network. The valve is positioned automatically by the cabin temperature control, or manually.

First, let me explain what the coldplates are. The coolant goes through these to remove heat from the electrical components. As the cold coolant enters the coldplates, the electrical components will be cooled down, at the same time as the coolant is heated up.

Based on the temperature setting, the coolant is either first routed through the heat exchanger before reaching the coldplates if cooling is needed, or it will go through the coldplates before the heat exchanger if heating is needed.
In the intermediate valve positions, the quantity of cool or warm water-glycol flowing through the heat exchanger is reduced in proportion to the demand for cooling or heating.
The total flow leaving the PRIMARY CABIN TEMP valve enters the primary pump and is recirculated.
The heat absorbed by the coolant in the primary loop is transported to the radiators where a portion is rejected to space. As coolant returns, the desired temperature should be around 45 °F nominal.
If it is below 45 °F, a mixing mode is enabled where some of the hot coolant is automatically bypassing the radiators and instead will mix with the cold coolant that returns from the radiators.

The automatic control (GLYCOL EVAP-TEMP IN switch, AUTO position) opens the PRIMARY GLYCOL EVAP INLET TEMP valve (panel 382), which allows enough hot coolant from the pump to mix with the coolant returning from the radiators, to produce a mixed temperature at the inlet to the evaporator between 43° and 48 °F.
If the radiators fail to radiate enough heat, the coolant returning to the CM will be above the desired temperature.
When the temperature of the coolant entering the evaporator rises to 48° to 50.5 °F, the evaporator mode of cooling is initiated.

The glycol temperature control (GLYCOL EVAP-STEAM PRESS switch, AUTO position) opens the steam pressure valve allowing water in the evaporator wicks to evaporate, using some of the heat contains in the coolant for the heat of vaporization.

A glycol temperature sensor at the outlet of the evaporator controls the position of the steam pressure valves to establish a rate of evaporation that will result in a coolant outlet temperature between 38° to 45 °F.
The evaporator wicks are maintained in a wet condition by the wetness control (GLYCOL EVAP-H2O FLOW switch, AUTO position), which uses the wick temperature as an indication of water content.
As the wicks become dryer, the wick temperature increases, and the water control valve is opened. As the wicks become wetter, the wick temperature decreases, and the water valve closes.
Let's take a closer look at the radiators.

The primary radiator circuit consists basically of two radiator panels, in parallel with a flow-proportioning control for dividing the flow between them, and a heater control for adding heat to the loop.
The radiator panels are an integral part of the SM skin and are located on the opposite sides of the SM (panel 1 in bays 2 and 3; panel 2 in bays 5 and 6).
With the radiators being diametrically opposite, it is possible that one primary panel may “see” deep space while the other “sees” the sun, earth, or moon.
These extremes in environments, provide for large differences in panel efficiencies  and outlet temperatures.

The panel seeing deep space can reject more heat than the panel receiving external radiation; therefore, the overall efficiency of the subsystem can be improved by increasing the flow to the cold panel.

Two electrical flow-proportioning valves, one active at a time, sends the coolant to the coldest of the two radiators. The No. 1 flow-proportioning valve is primarily used, while the No. 2 flow-proportioning valve is used if No. 1 fails.
You can also manually control what radiator to use if FLOW CONT is set to MAN SEL, and the MAN SEL sw is set to either RAD 1 or RAD 2. Leave the FLOW CONT in PWR.
You can select what flow-proportioning valve to use if the FLOW CONT is set to PWR and the AUTO-1-2 switch is set to 1 or 2. Leave it in AUTO.

Heaters in the radiators will automatically kick in if the outlet temperature is below -15F. Two heater systems, PRIM 1 and PRIM 2, can be used. Only one operates at a time, and is cycled based on the ECS REDUNDANT COMPONENTS checklist. Set it to PRIM 1.
Lastly, I would like to briefly talk about some of the procedures that needs to be done during a mission.

An ECS monitoring check is recommended every hour from the time the SC attains orbit until CSM separation. This check provides you with latest status of the ECS. A dedicated checklist can be use to do this. I would recommend you to run though this now.

The redundant component check is accomplished at 24-hour intervals to determine operational status of certain ECS redundant components and secondary water-glycol loop. I recommend you to read through the checklist now and get familiar with it before proceeding.

Replacement of one CO2-odor absorber filter is required on an alternate basis, at 12-our intervals, for the ECS to remain within prescribed metabolic limit. Filters are also changed if CO2 partial pressure exceeds 7.6 mm Hg. A checklist exists for this too but we did this earlier.
This concludes the lesson, it was a long one so take a well deserved break.

Title: THE ECS LESSON
Description:
The environmental control system (ECS) is designed to provide the flight crew with a conditioned environment that is both life-supporting, and as comfortable as possible. The ECS is aided in the accomplishment of this task through an interface with the electrical power system, which supplies oxygen and potable water.

In this lesson we will dive into the ECS and how to operate it.
